Carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation is an important model reaction frequently studied in catalysis and environmental decontamination. Although temperature-dependent CO oxidation has been confirmed experimentally, the computational studies on the activity impact of temperature on this process have rarely been investigated. The chemically nonequivalent surface oxygen atoms (Ob and Oc) of phosphotungstic acid (PTA) will be activated by introducing metal atoms, which could achieve catalytic CO oxidation via the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. Density functional theory computations on CO oxidation over Pd1/PTA SACs at various temperatures (100 to 700 K) were systemically examined, aiming at exploring the difference in activity of Ob and Oc atoms and the effect of temperature on CO oxidation. Based on optimized geometry, natural bond orbital, molecular orbital, Mulliken spin density, and spin population analysis of the catalyst, the Oc atom was predicted to have higher activity, which was subsequently elaborated by calculated free energy profiles of both oxygen vacancy formation paths. Moreover, a strong dependence of temperature on catalytic CO oxidation was clearly observed and even changes the rate-determining step. The computational results provide new insight into the differences in catalytic activities of surface oxygen species and the influence of temperature on the catalytic performance of CO oxidation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single–atom catalysts CO oxidation Density functional theory Temperature-dependent Surface oxygen species 1 Introduction Because of high stability and catalytic activity, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted a great deal of attention from many scientists engaged in catalysis research [1–5]. The Pt1/FeO x SACs have been reported to show high stability and excellent performance for CO selective oxidation in hydrogen, which is 2–3 times more active than nanoscale metallic catalysts [6]. Furthermore, SACs with 100% metal dispersity and maximum atom efficiency exhibit low metal consumption, which is an advantageous innovation strategy for the development of noble metals-based catalysts such as Os, Pd, Pt, Au, Ru, and Rh [7–11]. As the single metal atoms themselves are prone to aggregation, suitable solid support for anchoring SACs is thus highly desired [12,13]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are anionic nanosized transition-metal oxygen clusters and are considered promising homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyst-support materials owing to their high structural stability and high-temperature resistance [14–16]. They are more like discrete fragments of the solid metal, different from the consecutive network structure of metal oxides [17–29]. The Keggin-type POM-supported SACs have been first prepared successfully by Yan's group [27]. Through experimental and computational studies, Pt SACs were shown to be highly monodisperse on the surface with a high metal loading of up to 1 wt%. The high Pt dispersion can be attributed to the unique discrete and separated “island” structure of the Keggin-type POM surface [27]. The Keggin-type POMs furnish a range of oxygen coordination sites and their island-like structure can serve as an anchor to hinder the agglomeration of metal SACs [11,30,31]. Simultaneously, POMs are cheap, abundant and green materials, thus making them widely used in the catalysis field [11,27,30-35]. Carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation is not only a model reaction often studied in the catalytic field, but also very important for maintaining clean air [36]. The selective conversion of CO oxidation to CO2 in H2 is known as a key step in the removal of CO in automotive emission control and fuel cell applications [28,37,38]. Previous studies have demonstrated that noble metal materials exhibited an extremely high catalytic performance toward the oxidation of CO molecules [39–45]. SACs can decrease the use of noble metals and thus are the most promising catalysts for CO oxidant science [5,6]. A multitude of phosphomolybdic acid and phosphotungstic acid (PTA)-supported noble metal SACs (M1/PTA) were reported and have been confirmed to exhibit high catalytic activity for small molecules, such as CO, CO2, N2, H2, NO and N2O [11,30-32,46-48]. Experimental and computational studies showed that the coordinated oxygen species in PTA-supported Rh and Pt systems are crucial for CO oxidation reaction via a Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism, in which the coordinated oxygen is removed by reacting with the adsorbed CO molecule [11,32,49,50]. It is noteworthy to mention that the coordinated oxygen species that anchored metal single atoms are chemical nonequivalent, consisting of two bridging oxygen (Ob) atoms and two corner oxygen (Oc) atoms [11]. Subsequently, a theoretical study clearly demonstrated that both the two coordinated oxygen species Ob and Oc in Pd-based PTA (Pd1/PTA) material are removed more readily than Rh and Pt-based PTA SACs [30]. Although the Pd1/PTA has great potential for catalytic performance, however, so far, there has been no report of assessment for CO oxidation. Meanwhile, the origin of the high activity of coordinated oxygen species remains elusive. Large studies have shown that catalytic performance is remarkably affected by the reaction temperature, and CO oxidation can be achieved at different temperatures [49,50]. Moreover, the adsorption strength of CO and O2 are temperature-dependent, which will directly determine the reaction mechanism [51]. There is, therefore, a great need for further investigations on CO oxidation at different temperatures. Herein, in this study, we systemically examined the catalytic activity of Pd1/PTA SACs for CO oxidation by O2 at different temperatures, using density functional theory (DFT) computations. The effect of Pd SACs on coordinated oxygen species of Pd1/PTA as well as the difference in their catalytic activity is clearly explained by geometries and electronic structures of reactant precursors. Meanwhile, we evaluate the catalytic performance of Pd1/PTA at various temperatures by comparing the gas adsorption strength and the free energy barriers. 2 Computational details All the computational studies were performed with the Gaussian 16 [52] program and the local meta-GGA exchange-correlation functional M06L [53]. All the geometry optimization and harmonic vibrational frequency analysis were conducted using 6–31G(d) basis set for main elements and LANL2DZ basis set for the W and Pd in the gas phase [54–56]. It is worth mentioning that in this work all the atoms were fully relaxed during the geometrical optimization process. The natural bond orbital (NBO) [57] was carried out at the same level of theory as above. Previous DFT investigations have shown a good performance of M06L functional in thermochemistry, thermochemical kinetics, and vibration frequency calculations for PTA systems [53]. To obtain more accurate electronic energies, high-accuracy computations of single-point energy were obtained for all the optimized structures at the same function with diffusion 6–31+G (d, p) basis set for main elements and SDD pseudo potential basis set for transition metal atoms. Thermal correction to Gibbs free energy at different temperatures was obtained by Shermo soft developed by Lu et al.[58]. The frontier molecular orbitals and spin densities were displayed and analyzed by Multiwfn [59] and VMD [60] software. The adsorption energy was calculated by the following equation. E ad ( A ) = E A − M − E M − E A Where E A−M, E M, and E A denote the total energies of the complex, the clean catalyst, and the free molecule, respectively. 3 Results and discussion According to previous investigations, the spin multiplicity of molecules varies from case to case with very different geometry structures, leading to different electronic structures and catalytic activity of nanoscale materials [61]. Accordingly, the single point energies of all the possible spin multiplicities of clean Pd1/PTA SACs and adsorbed one O2, one CO2, one CO and two CO on Pd1/PTA systems were calculated and presented in Supplementary Table S1. Meanwhile, for all subsequent discussions, the energies of all the transition states, intermediate states, and final states are based on the most stable spin multiplicities. 3.1 Activation of different coordinated oxygen atoms It is well known PTA is a typical Keggin POM with a stoichiometry of H3PW12O40, where a PO4 3- subunit is confined in a neutral W12O36 cage [62–64]. Both experimental and computational researches show that the surface oxygens of PTA can readily bind a transition metal atom via a strong electrostatic interaction [28,49]. Also, the 4-hold hollow site was identified and confirmed to be the only possible adsorption site, which was formed by four surface oxygen atoms (Fig. 1 ) [11,28,48,49]. It is worth noting that the Ob and Oc atoms are chemically inequivalent, thus giving different catalytic activities for CO molecules [11,32]. Because of the inequivalence of surface oxygen of PTA, the degree of Ob and Oc atoms were simultaneously assessed when the Pd atom binds to PTA (Fig. 2 a and b). The optimized W–Ob and W–Oc bond lengths free PTA and Pd1/PTA are 1.924 and 1.932 Å, and 2.111 and 2.084 Å, respectively, and the corresponding W–Ob–W and W–Oc–W bond angle are 152° and 127°, and 145° and 122°, respectively. The bond length of W–Ob and W–Oc increases, and the bond angle of W–Ob–W and W–Oc–W decreases, both indicating that the surface oxygen Ob and Oc are highly activated, which could be attributed to the effect of anchoring Pd metal atom. The previous study [11] showed that the W–Oc bond length in Rh1/PTA is 2.060 Å, longer than that in Pd1/PTA, suggesting that the Oc in Pd1/PTA could have better catalytic activity. After anchoring Pd SACs, the calculated NPA atomic charges of Ob and Oc change from −0.712 to −0.682 e, and −0.703 to −0.742 e, indicating that introduction of Pd atom on the PTA surface will result in charge rearrangement of the surface Ob and Oc atom. As both the NPA atomic charges of coordinated Ob and Oc are influenced by three metals (two W atoms and one Pd atom), the differences are small in absolute value (0.03 vs 0.039). Therefore, the increase and decrease in the NPA atomic charges of Ob and Oc, cannot be explained clearly. The NPA atomic charges of Ob and Oc atoms in a series of PTA-supported SACs are also presented in Table S2. All the absolute value differences are small and show different trends. It can be concluded that there is no regular trend for Ob and Oc atoms after anchoring single metal atoms. 3.2 Adsorption of one O2, one CO2, one CO and two CO on Pd1/PTA SACs at different temperatures The catalytic activity of a catalyst largely depends on the gas adsorption (CO and O2) capability at the catalytic active centers. Meanwhile, too strong an interaction between the CO2 product and the Pd active center may lead to Pd1/PTA SACs poisoning. Consequently, the adsorption of one O2, one CO2, one CO, and two CO molecules, and co-adsorption of one CO and one O2 over the Pd1/PTA SACs surfaces at different temperatures were systemically examined. As shown in Fig. S1, there are two possible adsorption structures for adsorbing one O2, two CO, and CO+O2. Only the most stable adsorption structure diagrams are presented in Fig. 3 a, and the corresponding adsorption energies at different temperatures ranging from 100 to 700 K are displayed in Fig. 3b, respectively. It is worth emphasizing that the O2 molecule is not adsorbed in a parallel position to the Pd1/PTA surface, which is different from other PTA-based metal SACs. Based on the adsorption energy results presented in Fig. 3b, it can be concluded that the weak adsorption energy of CO2 at all temperatures indicates that Pd1/PTA SACs poisoning not occur in this work. Moreover, the adsorption strength of O2, CO2, and CO molecules have a similar trend, decreasing with the increase in temperature. The adsorption of two CO molecules has the largest adsorption energies in all cases, which is consistent with the previous experimental results. As a consequence, the Pd1/PTA adsorbed two CO molecules (denoted as CO*) is starting structure for the whole catalytic cycle, which is known as the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. The adsorption strength of two CO molecules reaches its maximum at 100 K with E ad value of −41.39 kcal mol−1, suggesting an interesting possibility of CO oxidation at low temperatures. 3.3 Prediction of different coordinated oxygen atoms activity based on the electronic structure of initial geometry As per the previous analysis (Section 3.1), the Pd single atom plays a crucial role in the activation of coordinated Ob and Oc in Pd1/PTA SACs. For further understanding the roles of Pd SACs and predicting the catalytic activity of Ob and Oc, the Pd-based molecular orbitals and spin densities of the initial geometry CO* are presented in Fig. 4 . Because the Pd3+ atom possesses the 3d7 configuration with an open–shell structure, the Pd-based molecular orbitals exist in both α– and β–spin configurations (Fig. 4a). As one can see, the α–HOMO-189, α–HOMO-217, α–HOMO-226, HOMO, β–HOMO-189, β–HOMO-217 and β–HOMO-226 orbitals are responsible for the Pd–CO nonbonding interaction. The α–HOMO-147 and β–HOMO-147 orbitals are composed of an overlap of the symmetry-adapted dxy orbitals of the Pd catalytic center with σ orbitals of CO molecule and p orbitals of two Ob atoms. Obviously, charge recombination may only occur on Ob atoms when adsorbing two CO molecules over the Pd1/PTA SACs compared with clean PTA. As expected, the calculated NPA charges of Ob and Oc in clean PTA and CO* are respectively −0.712 e vs −0.672 e, and −0.703 e vs −0.701 e (Fig. 2a and Fig. 4b), fully consistent with expectation. All the Pd-based molecular orbitals except the β–LUMO orbital are occupied solely by electrons. Consequently, the Pd single atom in this CO* complex has a σ2 xyd2 x 2-y2d2 xzd2 yzd1 z2 configuration. The above-described analysis clearly shows that the single metal Pd atom plays the role of electron acceptor while the two surface Ob atom and two adsorbed CO molecules act as electron donors. Spin density refers to the density of unpaired electrons and often correlates with the catalytic activity of atoms. Fig. 4b shows that the spin density is mainly distributed to the Pd center and Oc atoms, which suggests that the Pd and Oc atoms have high electron density with spin populations of 0.315 and 0.244, respectively. However, only a small amount of spin density is delocalized to Ob atoms with a spin population of 0.092, indicative of lower catalytic activity than Oc atoms. 3.4 Mechanistic cycles of CO oxidation on Pd1/PTA SACs at various temperatures The mechanistic cycles of CO oxidation by O2 on Pd1/PTA SACs via MvK mechanism are shown in Fig. 5 . According to the adsorption energies calculation, the geometry with adsorption of two CO molecules on Pd1/PTA is assigned as the initial state (CO*) for the overall catalytic process. As the surface Ob and Oc atoms of PTA are chemical nonequivalent for CO oxidant, the oxygen vacancy formation of removing Ob and Oc atoms should be both investigated here. Along with the MvK mechanism, one adsorbed CO molecule in CO* reacts with the coordinated Ob or Oc to form an Ob or Oc vacancy with a weak adsorbed CO2 molecule (CO2*@PdvOv,b and CO2*@PdvOv,c ) via transition states, TS1b and TS1c , respectively. The calculated free energy profiles for the removal Ob and Oc atom on Pd1/PTA SACs at different temperatures through the MvK mechanism are presented in Fig. 6 and Fig. S2, respectively. The calculated energy barriers at 100 to 700 K for TS1b and TS1c range from 12.39 to 14.52 kcal mol−1, and 5.07 to 9.70 kcal mol−1, respectively. Therefore, it can be concluded that the energy barriers of both TS1b and TS1c increase with the increase in temperature. As we introduced earlier, the Oc atom exhibits a higher catalytic performance than Ob atom due to the lower TS1b values at any temperature. As a result, the Oc vacancy formation path is more favorable for removing surface oxygen in this work. Thus, only the coordinated Oc atom is examined for CO oxidation in the following sections. The formed CO2 molecule in CO2*@Pdv-Ov,c is considered easily desorbed (Pdv-Ov,c ) since even at the hardest temperature (100 K), the calculated CO2 desorption process is only endothermic by 6.81 kcal mol−1. Subsequently, CO is adsorbed on the Pd single center and the Oc vacancy is refilled by O2. Based on DFT calculations, both the CO and O2 adsorptions get weaker with an increase in temperature, similar to that of a clean Pd1/PTA catalyst. The calculated E ad of CO is ranging from −16.25 to −0.17 kcal mol−1 (100 to 700 K), indicating that the CO adsorption process (CO*@Ov,c ) is exothermic at any time. Unfortunately, as temperature goes up, the O2 adsorption process ([CO*+O2*]c ) is exothermic at the beginning (from 100 to 300 K) and gradually changed to endothermic (from 350 to 700 K). This leads to a large increase in energy barriers of TS2c at temperatures between 350 and 700 K (dashed red line in Fig. 6). The formed intermediate [CO*-O2*]c via a transition state TS2c is stable because of its lower energy compared to the precursor [CO*+O2*]c . Previous work showed that the similar intermediate in Pt1/PTA system was an unstable structure [32], which again indicates the excellent potential of Pd1/PTA SACs for CO oxidation. The one O atom of adsorbed O2 molecule is further abstracted by the adsorbed CO molecule to form a weak adsorbed CO2 molecule (CO2*-Pd1 ) via a transition state TS3c . With increasing temperature, the energy barriers of TS3c become smaller, differing from that of TS1c and TS2c . The CO2 molecule desorption in CO2*-Pd1 is also easy and will lead to an unsaturated Pd site (Pd1 ). With a fresh CO adsorbed on the Pd center (CO*), the whole catalytic cycle of CO oxidation by O2 via the MvK mechanism is completed. To summarize this part, the reaction curve of the 100 K temperature almost locates at the bottom and gradually rises as the temperature increases, which indicates that the adverse effect of thermodynamics increases with increasing temperature. Meanwhile, the gradually diminished adsorption strength of the two CO molecules (on Pdv-Ov,c and Pd1 ) and O2 molecule (on Pd1 ) again suggests an energetically unfavorable process for CO oxidation. With increasing the temperature from 100 to 700 K, all the energies of intermediates and TS structures, and the free CO and CO2 molecules are continuously decreased. However, these trends of reduction vary from case to case, which results in different energy variation trends for different structures with increasing temperatures. As shown in Fig. 6, the energies of the intermediates CO2*@Pdv-Ov,c, Pdv-Ov,c and CO*@Ov,c show opposite trends to the other intermediates as the temperature changes. Interestingly, the rate-determining step changes as temperature changes, namely, TS3c in low temperature (100 to 350 K) and TS2c (400 to 700 K) in high temperature, indicating that the energy barrier of rate-determining step decreases (from 12.69 to 11.76 kcal mol−1) and then increases (from 12.12 to 29.73 kcal mol−1) as temperature rises. Combined with thermodynamic analysis, it can be concluded that the Pd1/PTA SACs would show high catalytic performance for CO oxidation when the temperature is below 350 K. 3.5 Charge variation of pd center along the oc vacancy formation path In order to gain further insight into the role of the anchoring Pd center in the whole catalytic reaction process, the charge variation of a single Pd atom is examined along the most favorable path as shown in Fig. 7 (Oc vacancy formation path). For MvK mechanism, the oxygen vacancy formation process is very important as it is the starting point of the reaction for CO oxidation. For CO* to TS1c , the NPA charge of the Pd center increases because the charge transfers from Pd to CO. Combining the Pd-based α–HOMO-147 and β–HOMO-147 orbitals (Fig. 4), the binding interaction of Pd-C bond will be weakened and therefore enhance its activity. The Pdv-Ov,c containing an Oc vacancy is the pivotal intermediate because it generates two new active sites for CO and O2 adsorption. Despite the presence of oxygen vacancy defect, the intermediate Pdv-Ov,c was confirmed to be a rather stable structure because of its lower energy compared to that of reactant CO* (Fig. 6). This result further proved that the Keggin-type POM has good structural stability. Along the whole catalytic path, the Pd center possesses the smallest NPA charge in Pdv-Ov,c (0.236), and the most charge in Pd1 (0.725). As a result, the catalytic Pd center serves as an electron acceptor in Oc vacancy formation and CO adsorption steps and an electron donor in the replenishing O2 and second CO oxidation steps, which suggests that the Pd center can be considered as an electron reservoir in the whole CO oxidation process. 4 Conclusion In the present work, CO oxidation by O2 on PTA-supported Pd1/PTA SACs via MvK mechanism at various temperatures from 100 to 700 K is systematically examined by means of DFT computations. The catalytic performance of two different types of coordinated oxygen atoms Ob and Oc in Pd1/PTA system was analyzed and predicted by optimized geometry, natural bond orbital, molecular orbital, Mulliken spin density and spin population analysis. The theoretical calculation results indicated that the Oc atom exhibited higher catalytic activity for CO molecules and was confirmed by a lower energy barrier of Oc vacancy formation path at any temperature than that of the Ob vacancy formation path (5.07 to 9.70 kcal mol−1 vs 12.39 to 14.52 kcal mol−1 with temperature varying from 100 to 700 K). The temperature influence on the values of the transition state indicates that the rate-determining step changes at around 350 to 400 K. It could be also concluded that, with the increase of temperature, the free energy barrier of the rate-determining step exhibits first a decreasing trend (from 12.69 to 11.76 kcal mol−1) and then increases (from 12.12 to 29.73 kcal mol−1). Furthermore, the highest activity for the CO molecule was reached when the temperature is below 350 K, by comparing gas adsorption strength, free energy barrier of the rate-determining step, and thermodynamic favorability of different temperatures. Further in-depth mechanistic studies of the differences in catalytic activities of surface oxygen species and CO oxidation at various temperatures have provided new engineering guidelines to design temperature-dependent catalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: Carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation is an important model reaction frequently studied in catalysis and environmental decontamination. Although temperature-dependent CO oxidation has been confirmed experimentally, the computational studies on the activity impact of temperature on this process have rarely been investigated. The chemically nonequivalent surface oxygen atoms (Ob and Oc) of phosphotungstic acid (PTA) will be activated by introducing metal atoms, which could achieve catalytic CO oxidation via the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. Density functional theory computations on CO oxidation over Pd1/PTA SACs at various temperatures (100 to 700 K) were systemically examined, aiming at exploring the difference in activity of Ob and Oc atoms and the effect of temperature on CO oxidation. Based on optimized geometry, natural bond orbital, molecular orbital, Mulliken spin density, and spin population analysis of the catalyst, the Oc atom was predicted to have higher activity, which was subsequently elaborated by calculated free energy profiles of both oxygen vacancy formation paths. Moreover, a strong dependence of temperature on catalytic CO oxidation was clearly observed and even changes the rate-determining step. The computational results provide new insight into the differences in catalytic activities of surface oxygen species and the influence of temperature on the catalytic performance of CO oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insight into surface oxygen species of the polyoxometalate-supported Pd single-atom catalysts for highly efficient CO oxidation
